results.title: How seeds are scattered
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “E.F.V.A. Primary Botany”.
Designed for primary schools, shows how plants produce flowers and then fruits which contain seeds. Different kinds of fruits and seeds - runner beans, laburnum tree, willow seeds, thistles, sycamore tree, are used to illustrate methods of dispersal by wind, water and animals.

results.title: How seeds are made
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “E.F.V.A. Primary Botany”.
The structure of flowers is explained with close-ups to show the male and female parts, stamens and stigma. Insects are seen visiting many different flowers, both wild and cultivated. Close-ups illustrate very clearly the relationship between the shapes of flowers and the shapes of the insects which pollinate them. Wind pollinated flowers are also shown, and their pollen grains, much magnified, are compared with those of the insect-pollinated flowers. An animated diagram makes clear the process of fertilisation which follows pollination.

results.title: Building belief. Pt. 2
results.creator_credit: Dana H. Hodgdon, Bernice Gregorio and Northwestern University Film Library
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dorothy Heathcote Teaching series”.
Dorothy Heathcote continues her work with a class of nine and ten year old American children. Using drama to create focus and feeling, she poses three moral dilemmas, where the children are confronted with crises involving leadership, old-age, and death. Suitable for teachers and tertiary level.

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dorothy Heathcote Teaching series”.
This film shows England’s outstanding drama educator, Dorothy Heathcote, working with nine and ten year old American children. She uses drama as a means of teaching social studies. Suitable for teachers and tertiary level.

results.title: Dorothy Heathcote talks to teachers. Pt. 1 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bernice Gregorio, Dana H. Hodgdon and Northwestern University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dorothy Heathcote Teaching series”.
In a teachers’ workshop, Dorothy Heathcote, England’s outstanding drama educator, explores the theory of improvised drama as a teaching tool for all classroom teachers. She analyses her unique process, explaining and illustrating techniques for developing materials, the use of dramatic elements and the segmenting of ideas to achieve dramatic focus.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bernice Gregorio, Dana H. Hodgdon and Northwestern University

results.title: Dorothy Heathcote talks to teachers. Pt. 2 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bernice Gregorio, Dana H. Hodgdon and Northwestern University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dorothy Heathcote Teaching series”.
Drama in the classroom continues with the discussion of techniques developed by Mrs. Heathcote. “Questioning”, “storyline”, “universals” and “brother hoods” are examined. Drama is related to developing language and social skills, while teaching subject material. Mrs. Heathcote’s educative process is based on total involvement that ultimately modifies behaviour.

results.title: Glass curtain
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Doris Chase Concepts”.
A dance film in which a woman tries to cope with the dimming mind of her mother who suffers from Alzheimer’s disease. Dancer Jennie Ventriss. Music by Katherine Hoover.
